docs.lead_paragraph: Management deserves a lot of the credit for Boston's triumph in the 2004 World Series, Seth Mnookin says.

headline.seo: 'Feeding the Monster: How Money, Smarts and Nerve Took a Team to the Top,' by Seth Mnookin - The New York Times Book Review

docs.lead_paragraph: No matter how many times Alex Rodriguez walks onto the same field as the Boston Red Sox, there will always be some intrigue and some tension. Rodriguez was willing to accept contract deferments to save the Red Sox $28 million in a trade, but it was nixed 21 months ago and he, surprisingly, ended up with the Yankees. It seems like an ancient story now, but Rodriguez was almost on the other side of the rivalry, almost chronically booed in the Bronx instead of in Boston. The Red Sox were angry when they lost Rodriguez to New York, but they managed to soothe themselves by winning the championship without him last year.
docs.snippet: On Friday night against the Red Sox, Alex Rodriguez, the $252 million man, kept producing for the Yankees....

headline.main: How Do Red Sox Hate Him? Let's Count the Ways

docs.lead_paragraph: The chatty starter named Curt Schilling has appeared on more sports talk radio shows in Boston than games for the Red Sox. David Wells, another motormouth starter, has won only two games and has even mused about nearing the end. Closer Keith Foulke has been miserable. Fans are treating Edgar Renteria, the $40 million shortstop, as if he is wearing a Derek Jeter mask. But Matt Clement and Bronson Arroyo, two thin-as-a-foul-pole pitchers who had question marks after the names on their uniforms, have combined to go 9-1. Johnny Damon has been Johnny Damon, only better. Jason Varitek, David Ortiz and Trot Nixon are performing as if a magical October bled into 2005.
docs.snippet: The defending World Series champions are coping so far without key pitching....

docs.lead_paragraph: The red carpet was set up outside the Green Monster. A Brinks truck rounded the corner, two gun-toting guards came out and cameras recorded it all. The ball used for the final out of the World Series finally reached Fenway Park on Thursday.
docs.abstract: Ball caught by Boston Red Sox first baseman Doug Mientkiewicz to end World Series is brought to Fenway Park (Mass) where it will stay for one year; photos (M)

headline.main: For Red Sox, Series Ball Is Finally Safe at Home

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE was a victory parade in Boston yesterday, but it still wasn't enough to honor the decades of Red Sox fans who lived and died without seeing the Red Sox win a World Series. On the night that the Red Sox won their first World Series championship since 1918, the hitting coach Ron Jackson spoke for the fans who were there in spirit only. ''I'm happy to be part of this,'' he said Wednesday night. ''I'm especially happy for all the people who came through that didn't get to the World Series from 1918 up to now.
docs.snippet: In a season of broken curses, Ron Jackson broke the jinx of the Red Sox hitting coach, a position that had become a revolving door....

headline.main: Red Sox Hitters Found A Mentor in Papa Jack

docs.lead_paragraph: GAME on. Go time. The World Series returns to Fenway Park tonight for the first time since 1986, when the Red Sox play host to the St. Louis Cardinals. With the region still hung over from the Sox' comeback against the Yankees in the American League Championship Series, Boston will be trying to win the World Series for the first time since 1918.
docs.snippet: A new generation of Boston fans has been born since the last time the Red Sox were in a World Series....

headline.main: The Boston Globe; Forget the Past, It's All New This Time

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox fired Tommy Harper, Bob Kipper and Dwight Evans from their coaching staff yesterday in moves that appear to secure Manager Grady Little's future with the team. The Red Sox also said that Mike Stanley, the bench coach, would leave for personal reasons. The pitching coach, Tony Cloninger, and the third-base coach, Mike Cubbage, were retained. No replacements were named.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox fire coaches Dwight Evans, Tommy Harper and Bob Klipper; no replacements named (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boston Red Sox took the next-to-last step in the sale of this century yesterday, accepting final bids for a majority ownership of a team that is one of the crown jewels of Major League Baseball. Perhaps the most critical element of the competition is that the 53 percent share of the Red Sox up for sale does not have to go to the highest bidder. Bids were expected to be in the range of $350 million to $400 million. According to a person familiar with a document provided to bidders, it says the ownership share will go not to the highest bidder, but to the highest qualified bidder.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox begin accepting final bids for majority ownership of team; critical element of competition is that 53 percent of share of team up for sale does not have to go to highest bidder but to highest qualified bidder (M)

headline.main: Red Sox Close Bidding For Majority Ownership

docs.lead_paragraph: The best pitcher on the team has bickered with the general manager about the severity of a shoulder injury and whether he should keep pitching. The best player, who is usually as cautious as a presidential press secretary, criticized the organization for demoting the acting pitching coach. That coach, in turn blasted the general manager, refused to accept his demotion and was fired. The $160 million hitter apparently wonders if he should have elected to play somewhere else. This is the Boston Red Sox in 2001, not the Yankees of the 1970's and 80's. The Franklin Park Zoo does not sound as sexy as the Bronx Zoo, the perfect moniker for George Steinbrenner's clubs whenever he meddled and they argued, but the Red Sox have now created as confusing a scene as those Yankees did. The season cannot disappear soon enough for the Red Sox.
docs.abstract: Boston Red Sox have terrific start to season but are imploding with myriad feuds and management miscues; photo (M)
